<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/51  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 767, 91]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows a small solid metal cylinder of mass \(m\), length \(L\) and diameter \(d\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 100, 606, 186]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 229, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
The cylinder is heated to a uniform temperature. The cylinder is then removed from the heat source and the cylinder is wrapped in an insulating material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 276, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the room is \(T_{\mathrm{R}}\). At time \(t\) after the cylinder starts to cool, the surface temperature of the cylinder is \(T_{\mathrm{C}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 323, 576, 342]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(T_{\mathrm{C}}\) is related to \(t\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 346, 583, 371]]<|/det|>
\[(T_{\mathrm{C}} - T_{\mathrm{R}}) = Ze^{-\frac{UA t}{mc}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 920, 426]]<|/det|>
where \(A\) is the total surface area of the cylinder, \(c\) is the specific heat capacity of the metal, and \(U\) and \(Z\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 439, 697, 458]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(T_{\mathrm{C}}\) and \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 625, 488]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 501, 702, 520]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(U\) and \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 532, 384, 550]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 564, 393, 581]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 594, 410, 611]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 625, 346, 642]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 656, 351, 673]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 687, 447, 704]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 811, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the sound from a horn attached to a car, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 101, 850, 266]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 276, 591, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 307, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
A microphone is placed at the side of the road and connected to a frequency meter. The car travels towards the microphone. The frequency \(f\) of the sound detected by the microphone is read from the frequency meter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
The speed of the car is measured by two speed detectors. The two measurements of speed are \(\nu_{1}\) and \(\nu_{2}\). The average speed \(\nu\) of the car is determined from \(\nu_{1}\) and \(\nu_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 598, 434]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different speeds of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 447, 564, 465]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(f\) and \(\nu\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 476, 536, 510]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{f_{\mathrm{s}}k}{k - \nu}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 516, 761, 535]]<|/det|>
where \(f_{\mathrm{s}}\) is the frequency of the sound emitted by the horn and \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 547, 146, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 543, 648, 570]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{f}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(v\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 611, 597]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 763, 917, 781]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 795, 917, 813]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 812, 920, 829]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 517, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(\nu_{1}, \nu_{2}\) and \(f\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 131, 895, 481]]<|/det|>
\(v_{1}/m s^{-1}\)\(v_{2}/m s^{-1}\)\(v/m s^{-1}\)\(f/Hz\)\(\frac{1}{f}/10^{-3}Hz^{-1}\)
3.13.9894.2
6.75.9901.2
9.28.2908.0
11.910.9915.8
13.314.5923.6
15.616.8931.2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 485, 724, 510]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\nu / \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) and \(\frac{1}{f} / 10^{-3} \text{Hz}^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 475, 539]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\nu\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 522, 920, 540]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 552, 144, 571]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 549, 180, 570]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 548, 757, 573]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{f} / 10^{-3} \text{Hz}^{-1}\) against \(\nu / \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\). Include error bars for \(\nu\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 584, 178, 603]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 583, 920, 617]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 630, 180, 648]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 629, 920, 663]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 814, 922, 833]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 210, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
\[y\mathrm{-intercept} = .................................................... [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 241, 180, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(f_{\mathrm{s}}\) and \(k\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 425, 917, 445]]<|/det|>
\[f_{\mathrm{s}} = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 457, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
\[k = ............................................................ [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 504, 181, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 547, 522]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 643, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty in \(k =\) ................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[916, 644, 922, 662]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 146, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 675, 865, 694]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated. Determine the speed \(v\) that gives a value of \(f\) of \(987.8 \text{Hz}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
<form>v = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[881, 829, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
